metadata.sermon_start_end: This is the first sermon of a series on Romans, since the lectionary assigns it to be read all this summer. [...] And grant, O most merciful Father, for his sake, that we may hereafter live a godly, righteous and sober life, to the glory of thy holy Name. Amen.
metadata.historical_context: Delivered in 1978, a period of burgeoning therapeutic culture and post-Victorian liberation. The sermon references Karl Menninger (1973) and the social climate of the late 70s Episcopal Church.
metadata.notes: This is a classic example of 'Theological Realism' within an Episcopal/Anglican framework.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon relies heavily on conceptual and biblical imagery rather than original sensory description. Rutledge utilizes the 'staccato' nature of Paul’s Greek and the literary imagery of William Golding’s 'Lord of the Flies' to ground the abstract concept of Sin. While the 'sinking lifeboat' and 'infection' metaphors are effective, they are somewhat conventional. The strength lies in the 'cinematic' use of the Golding illustration, which provides a vivid, dark picture of human nature. However, the sermon often 'tells' the theology of Romans rather than 'showing' it through fresh, sensory-rich narratives. It functions more as a high-level intellectual 'optics' than a visceral sensory experience.
quotes: Sin is a disease, an infection, that the whole human race has got.
The officer... prepares to take the children off the island in a cruiser which will presently be hunting its enemy in the same implacable way.
Let us submit to the word of the apostle, as sisters and brothers in the same sinking lifeboat.
strengths: Effective use of literary imagery (Lord of the Flies) to illustrate total depravity.
Strong use of the 'staccato' metaphor to describe Paul's rhetorical style.
Clear distinction between 'sins' (plural) and 'Sin' (singular) through medical/spatial metaphors.
improvement_points: Incorporate more contemporary sensory details to ground the 'wrath' in modern experience.
Move beyond 'telling' the biblical list of sins to 'showing' one in a modern vignette.
Use more varied metaphors for 'grace' to balance the heavy 'infection' imagery.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Predominantly 'tell'. The sermon explains the mechanics of Romans with great clarity but relies on external literature (Golding) to do the heavy lifting of 'showing'.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: Rutledge exhibits exceptional stewardship of language. Her word choice is precise, particularly in her refusal to use 'Canaanite' jargon without defining it. She rehabilitates the word 'Sin' by stripping away Victorian connotations and redefining it with theological rigor. The language is economical and avoids the 'beautifying' fluff that Cilliers warns against. There is a clear, sober beauty in her prose that respects the gravity of the subject matter. The precision with which she distinguishes between 'sins' and 'Sin' is a hallmark of linguistic care, ensuring the hearer cannot hide behind vague definitions.
quotes: Sin is not a matter of a few sins here and a few sins there... it is a demonic Power that enslaves us.
There is no advanced placement here, no inner circle, no honor roll.
strengths: High degree of precision in defining theological terms.
Avoidance of religious clichés; every word feels weighed and intentional.
Effective 'de-jargonizing' of the term 'Wrath of God'.
improvement_points: The transition between the Menninger quote and the Golding quote could be more fluid.
Some sentences are slightly long for oral delivery, though the rhythm remains clear.
Could further specify what 'glory of God' looks like in contemporary language.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Excellent. Jargon like 'Wrath' and 'Sin' is not avoided but is carefully unpacked and 'reframed' for a modern audience.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon possesses a rhythmic quality that mirrors the 'staccato' negation she identifies in Luther. There is a deliberate cadence, moving from the 'they' of the outsiders to the 'you' of the congregation. The repetition of 'guilty of...' near the end creates a powerful rhetorical crescendo that leads naturally into the General Confession. The sentence structure varies between short, punchy declarations and longer, explanatory periods. It is clearly written for the ear, maintaining a steady 'beat' that sustains the heavy thematic weight without becoming monotonous or bureaucratic.
quotes: There is no distinction, since all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.
They are gossips, slanderers, haters of God, insolent, haughty, boastful...
Guilty of hurting our spouses... guilty of self-indulgence... guilty of jealousy...
strengths: Strong use of anaphora (repetition) in the concluding section.
Rhythmic variation that prevents the heavy subject matter from feeling 'flat'.
The sermon 'sounds' like a courtroom drama, fitting the forensic nature of Romans.
improvement_points: The middle section involving Menninger is slightly more 'prose-heavy' and loses some rhythmic drive.
Could use more alliteration or assonance to make key theological points 'stickier'.
The transition to the final prayer is abrupt, though liturgically appropriate.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Oral language. Despite the intellectual depth, the phrasing is designed for the pulpit, not the journal.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The poetics of the sermon are characterized by a 'sober beauty' and high linguistic precision. Rutledge avoids the 'kitsch' of flowery language, opting instead for a sharp, almost forensic clarity. While the imagery is more literary than sensory, it effectively 'reframes' the biblical text for a 1970s audience. The rhythm is well-paced, building toward a liturgical climax. It is a work of 'stewardship of language' that treats words as serious instruments of truth, successfully avoiding the 'paper language' of academic theology while maintaining intellectual rigor.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a masterful dramaturgical arc that Paul Scott Wilson would recognize as 'The Four Pages' in reverse or a 'Lowry Loop'. It begins by 'upsetting the equilibrium'—challenging the hearer's comfort with the Gospel by introducing the 'Wrath of God'. The movement is a 'trap': it starts with 'them' (the sinners), moves to 'you' (the religious), and ends with 'us' (the sinking lifeboat). This creates a palpable tension that is intentionally *not* resolved within the sermon itself, but deferred to the liturgy (the Confession). The 'plot' is the movement from self-righteousness to the 'wretched man' of Romans 7.
quotes: I thought about calling it ‘The Wrath of God,’ but... I want to keep my job.
But Paul turns the argument around. Instead of saying they, he suddenly starts saying you.
This sermon is going to come to an end in a minute. We are not going to turn the corner today.
strengths: Excellent 'homiletical plot' that draws the listener into the 'trap' of the text.
High tension sustained by refusing to offer a 'cheap' happy ending.
The structure perfectly mirrors the rhetorical movement of the Epistle to the Romans.
improvement_points: The introduction is a bit 'meta' (talking about the title); a more narrative 'hook' could increase initial tension.
The transition from the 'Lord of the Flies' back to the sermon conclusion is very rapid.
Could have leaned even more into the 'wretched man' tension before the final prayer.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: Dynamic journey. It is a purposeful descent into the reality of sin, designed to make the subsequent liturgy necessary.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is a textbook example of Cilliers' 'reframing'. Rutledge takes the ancient, often-dismissed concept of 'Wrath' and 'Original Sin' and reframes them through modern psychiatry (Menninger) and modern literature (Golding). She honors the 'strangeness' of the biblical text—refusing to smooth over the parts that 'don't do well in the Episcopal Church'—and uses that very strangeness to critique the contemporary context. The integration is organic; the context (the 1970s 'disappearance of sin') is used to highlight why the ancient text is more 'realistic' than modern optimism.
quotes: Most of us would probably risk unpopularity sooner than we would risk being thought passé.
The Jews are the in-group, the religious aristocracy, the Episcopalians, if you will.
And who will rescue the adult and his cruiser?
strengths: Brilliant 'reframing' of the Jewish/Gentile distinction into 'Episcopalian/Outsider'.
Uses secular sources (Menninger/Golding) not as 'fluff' but as witnesses to the text's truth.
Respects the 'otherness' of the text while making it devastatingly relevant.
improvement_points: Could have addressed the 'July 2nd' (Independence Day weekend) context more specifically regarding national 'sin'.
The Menninger reference, while strong, dates the sermon to the 70s; a more timeless contextual bridge could be used.
Could explore the 'Gentile' side of the context more—who are the 'outsiders' today?
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes. It reframes the 'moral life' as a form of 'storing up wrath', a radical shift for a 'good' congregation.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: Following Ciska Stark’s 'Open Work of Art', this sermon is remarkably open because it refuses to 'close' the theological loop. Rutledge explicitly states, 'We are not going to turn the corner today.' By leaving the congregation in the 'wretchedness' of Romans 7, she creates an 'open' space that only the grace of God (in the following liturgy/Eucharist) can fill. However, the interpretation of the text itself is quite 'closed' in a dogmatic sense—she is very firm on what Paul means. The 'openness' is existential rather than interpretive; the hearer is left with a question, not a neat package.
quotes: We are not going to turn the corner today. It is good for us to sit with Paul’s words for a while.
Who will deliver us from this body of death?
Today we are trying to avoid the easy assumptions that Catherine was mocking.
strengths: Refusal to provide a 'happy ending' creates a deep aesthetic and spiritual 'openness'.
Approaches the hearer as a mature partner capable of sitting with 'the worst of the problem'.
The sermon ends as an 'invitation' to the Confession, not a 'conclusion' of the topic.
improvement_points: The dogmatic tone regarding 'what the Bible means' could feel 'closed' to those struggling with the text's logic.
Could allow for more 'polyphony' regarding how people experience 'wrath'.
The ending is liturgically closed, though existentially open.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Existentially open, dogmatically focused. It creates space by withholding the 'answer' until the very end (and even then, deferring to the liturgy).

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic structure is the sermon's greatest strength. Rutledge employs a sophisticated 'reframing' technique and a narrative arc that purposefully leads the congregation into a 'dead end' of self-justification. By refusing to 'turn the corner' to grace prematurely, she avoids religious kitsch and respects the 'dramaturgy of the Spirit'. The sermon functions as a 'scene' in a larger liturgical drama, demonstrating a profound understanding of the sermon as an 'event' in time rather than a static lecture.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: This sermon is a powerful antidote to religious kitsch. Rutledge explicitly attacks 'sentimental evasions' and 'cheap' grace. She avoids the 'happy ending' cliché and the 'pre-chewed emotions' of easy comfort. By forcing the congregation to 'look Sin straight in the face' without immediate resolution, she achieves authentic aesthetic depth. The use of Golding’s dark imagery further prevents any descent into sentimentality. The sermon is 'sober' in the best Reformed/Anglican sense, honoring the 'pain of the problem' before the 'joy of the solution'.
examples_of_kitsch: The mocking mention of Catherine the Great's 'God forgives—it's his thing' (as a warning against kitsch).
The rejection of the 'Victorian hang-ups' view of sin as a superficial modern cliché.
authentic_moments: The admission that she might 'lose her job' for preaching on wrath, signaling the cost of truth.
The 'sinking lifeboat' metaphor which places the preacher and congregation in the same desperate reality.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain this 'tragic' aesthetic; it is what gives the eventual proclamation of grace its 'weight' (glory).

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Paradoxically, by focusing on 'Wrath' and 'Sin', Rutledge opens a profound 'Space for Grace'. As Cilliers suggests, grace is only 'grace' when it is situated in the 'between' of our despair and God's holiness. By 'reframing' reality as a 'sinking lifeboat', she creates the vacuum that grace is meant to fill. She sustains the tension of 'wretchedness' (Romans 7) without resolving it cheaply, thereby respecting the 'mystery' of how God acts. The 'space' here is the space of the 'penitent'—a wide, honest space where God can actually appear.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: Yes, the tension is the primary aesthetic engine of the sermon. She explicitly refuses to resolve it.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: Yes, by not explaining away the 'Wrath of God' as a mere human emotion, she preserves the 'Otherness' of God.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails, but only as a 'hidden' reality that makes the diagnosis of sin possible. It is not moralistic because she includes herself in the 'no distinction'.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: The 'Space for Grace' could be further enlarged by a brief 'glimmer' of the 'Power' of the Gospel mentioned in Rom 1:16, to ensure the 'space' doesn't become 'void'.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust example of 'Theological Realism'. Its beauty lies not in 'beautifying' the message, but in the 'sober beauty' of truth-telling. Rutledge avoids the pitfalls of religious kitsch by leaning into the 'staccato negation' of the text. The poetics are precise and the dramaturgy is intentionally provocative, leading the hearer through a 'reframing' of their own moral standing. By refusing to 'turn the corner' to a cheap resolution, the sermon creates a profound 'Space for Grace' that is completed only in the liturgical act of confession. It is an 'open work' in the sense that it leaves the hearer in a state of 'holy unrest'.
strengths_top_3: Masterful 'reframing' of ancient theological categories for a modern audience.
Authentic, anti-kitsch approach that takes human suffering and sin seriously.
Strong dramaturgical arc that mirrors the rhetorical 'trap' of the Epistle to the Romans.
improvement_points_top_3: Increase sensory 'showing' to complement the high-level intellectual 'telling'.
Soften the 'academic' tone of the middle section to maintain rhythmic momentum.
Provide a slightly more vivid 'glimmer' of the grace that 'encloses' the wrath.
overall_aesthetics.primary_aesthetic_style: Sober-Reformed / Narrative-Dramatic. It combines the 'sober beauty' of the Reformed tradition with the 'dramatic trap' of the New Homiletic.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Anti-kitsch) and Paul Scott Wilson (The Four Pages/Tension between Trouble and Grace).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to 'intellectual-seekers' and 'liturgically-minded' hearers who value honesty over sentimentality.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Use the 'Space for Grace' created here to deliver a sensory-rich 'Page 4' (Grace in the World) in the next sermon.
Experiment with a contemporary 'parable' to 'show' the 'Power of Sin' in a domestic setting.
Maintain the 'witness' stance (Thomas Long) rather than the 'teacher' stance.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: Through the lens of homiletic aesthetics, this sermon is a high-quality 'event'. It succeeds because the 'how' (the suspense, the literary depth, the refusal of kitsch) is perfectly aligned with the 'what' (the radical leveling of 'no distinction'). It is a courageous sermon that trusts the aesthetic power of the 'Word' to convict without needing to 'sell' it with superficial beauty. It stands as a model of how to preach 'unpopular' doctrines with aesthetic integrity and theological depth.
